text: GIMEL. Deal bountifully with thy servant, that I may live, and keep thy word.
text_kjv: GIMEL. Deal bountifully with thy servant, that I may live, and keep thy word.
text_niv: ג GimelDo good to your servant, and I will live;I will obey your word.
text_esv: Deal bountifully with your servant, that I may live and keep your word.
text_nlt: Be good to your servant,that I may live and obey your word.
text_msg: Be generous with me and I'll live a full life;not for a minute will I take my eyes off your road.
text_nasb: Deal bountifully with Your servant, That I may live and keep Your word.
context: Psalm 119, an acrostic poem, is a meditation on the Torah, God's law and instruction. Each section is headed by a letter of the Hebrew alphabet, and each verse within a section begins with that letter. This verse opens the 'Gimel' section. 'Gimel' (גִּימֶל) is the third letter of the Hebrew alphabet. The acrostic structure underscores the comprehensive nature of God's word, suggesting that it covers the whole spectrum of life and thought. In ancient Israel, the law wasn't merely a set of rules but a comprehensive guide for righteous living encompassing moral, social, and religious aspects. 'Servant' (עֶבֶד, eved) implies a voluntary submission and devotion to God. In ancient Near Eastern society, being a servant to a king or deity was considered an honor, signifying both obligation and protection. The idea of 'living' was not just physical survival; it encompassed spiritual vitality and a life pleasing to God. 'Keeping' God's word meant not just knowing it, but actively obeying and integrating it into every facet of life. The concept of 'bountifully dealing' highlights God's generosity and abundance, exceeding what is strictly deserved. It speaks to the covenant relationship where God delights to bless those who are faithful.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 119:17 reveals a profound understanding of grace and works interwoven in the believer's life. The Psalmist, acknowledging himself as God's 'servant,' is not claiming merit but emphasizing his commitment to obedience. His prayer for God to 'deal bountifully' acknowledges dependence on God's unmerited favor, which is the essence of grace. 'That I may live' implies more than mere physical existence; it signifies spiritual life, a life characterized by intimacy with God and conformity to His will. This echoes the New Testament concept of 'eternal life' which is not merely existing forever but knowing God (John 17:3). 'And keep thy word' is not presented as a prerequisite for God's favor, but as a consequence of it. The bountiful dealing of God empowers and enables obedience. This verse illustrates the reformed theological concept of prevenient grace – God's grace that comes before, enabling us to even desire and choose Him. Keeping God's word is not a legalistic burden but a joyful response to His grace, demonstrating a heart transformed by His love. The prayer acknowledges that genuine obedience flows from a heart touched and enabled by God's overflowing kindness, a testament to the transforming power of divine grace operating in the life of a believer.
application: In modern life, Psalm 119:17 serves as a powerful reminder to rely on God's grace in our pursuit of holiness. We often strive for obedience as a means to earn God's favor, leading to frustration and legalism. This verse invites us to shift our perspective, recognizing that genuine obedience springs from a heart overflowing with gratitude for God's undeserved kindness. Practically, this means beginning each day with prayer, asking God to deal bountifully with us, pouring out His grace and empowering us to live according to His will. This also requires honest self-reflection, acknowledging our dependence on God's strength to overcome sin and temptation. We must immerse ourselves in God's word, not as a checklist of rules, but as a source of life, wisdom, and guidance. This involves consistent Bible reading, meditation, and application of biblical principles in our daily interactions and decisions. When we face challenges or failures, we should not despair but turn to God in repentance, trusting in His grace to forgive and restore us. Engaging in practices that foster spiritual growth, such as prayer, fellowship, and service, are tangible ways to cultivate a life that pleases God. Furthermore, we should seek out mentors and accountability partners who can encourage and challenge us in our walk with Christ. Finally, actively seek opportunities to share the grace and truth of God's word with others, pointing them to the source of true life and freedom.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before You as Your servant, acknowledging my dependence on Your grace. I ask that You deal bountifully with me today. Pour out Your spirit upon me, granting me the strength and wisdom to live a life that honors You. Help me to internalize Your word, not just as information, but as a living truth that transforms my heart and mind. Enable me to keep Your commandments, not out of obligation, but out of a deep love and gratitude for all that You have done for me. Forgive me for the times I have relied on my own strength and failed to live up to Your standards. Fill me with Your grace, that I may walk in obedience and experience the fullness of life You have promised. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'deal bountifully' means to treat with great generosity and abundance, exceeding what is deserved or expected. It's God's way of showering blessings beyond our merit, a characteristic of His covenant love.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'deal bountifully'?

faqs.answer: The Psalmist acknowledges that obedience is a result of God's grace. By asking for bountiful dealing first, he recognizes that God's grace empowers him to keep His word, rather than earning it.
faqs.question: Q2: Why does the Psalmist ask for God to deal bountifully before mentioning obedience?

faqs.answer: This verse offers hope by reminding us that God's grace is sufficient to overcome temptation. We can pray for His bountiful dealing to provide the strength and wisdom to resist sin.
faqs.question: Q3: How is this verse relevant to someone struggling with temptation?

faqs.answer: No. While physical life is included, the Psalmist likely refers to spiritual life, vitality, and a life aligned with God's purpose, which are all intertwined in his worldview.
faqs.question: Q4: Does this verse imply that physical life is the only kind of 'life' the Psalmist is concerned with?

faqs.answer: This verse aligns with the New Testament understanding that salvation is by grace through faith. God's bountiful dealing is akin to His saving grace, enabling us to live righteously.
faqs.question: Q5: How does this verse relate to the concept of salvation in the New Testament?
